head.title: Schooner Nancy, Log and Lists of Provisions, 1811-1813. - Page #7

body.p: << First Page | < Previous Page | Page #7 of 71 | Next Page > | Last Page >>

td.p: Mackintosh, Alexander. Schooner Nancy, Log and Lists of Provisions, 1811-1813. An electronic transcription. MFTP #0039

div.p: Remarks on board the Schooner Nancy at anchor in Sandusky Bay in the month of July August 1813[.]

latter part of this day fresh breezes at NE & clear weather – sent a ps of rope to Mr Miller commanding the Ellen which had been taken by mistake from his vessel on monday night of our departure from Amherstburg – he refuses to receive it – at the same time occupying the Men who came out with him of having stolen it – at 4 PM wind encreases at 7 paid our more cable & set the main stay up – discern a sail doubling the West end of Pudding bay Island – suppose her to be the Chippewa – last part of this 24 hours less wind & clear weather[.] about 3 PM heard several shot fire

Fore part of this 24 hours light airs at East, at 8 AM see the same vessel beating up for us to leeward of Cunninghams Island, at 9 went on Shore i:e: on the River huron side of the Sandusky Lake, discover several fresh human tracks & a number of tracks of Cattle, –stood into the Lake & hauled up for a bay on the larboard [shore] see nothing – returned to the opposite Shore & took some hay on board for sheep – wind freshens from the NE, Clear pleasant warm weather, at about 4 PM heard several guns fire in the direction of Sandusky – the Chippewa makes a signal, blue at the fore top gallant mast head, & Ensign at main peak – answered hoisting the consign at the staff head, at 5 passes by I suppose with an intention of running into the Lake, go in pursuit of her with the boat, to warn her of going into shoal water she comes to, a boat arrives from the Camp of the army – for provisions – Colonel Evans of the 41st Regt […] Several officers & men arrive in the Chippewa to join the army – latter part winds abates, warm & Sultry at 8 PM set the watch, mounted a 3 poud field piece on Deck[.]

I this day sounded the Entrance into the Lake Sandusky & across the Entrance, discover a channel about 20 fathom wide with soundings of 4 to 5 fathom water running in a SW direction & close to the larboard shore (or Rr Huron Side), on the NW side off the entrance there is a shoal which runs of some distance say a ¼ of a mile on which there is i[n] some places 3 feet water & most 6 to 5 feet[.]

td.p:
L E G E N D :
in red , modifications made by the editor(s).
in lavender , modifications made by the assumed author(s).
